articles.headline: The Pilot in the Cockpit? In Japan, He Might Be a Retiree
articles.snippet: Many retired people in the country have returned to the work force as the population dwindles and jobs go unfilled, including Shigekazu Miyazaki, who is still flying at 65.
articles.abstract: Many retired people in the country have returned to the work force as the population dwindles and jobs go unfilled, including Shigekazu Miyazaki, who is still flying at 65.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAGASAKI, Japan — Shigekazu Miyazaki is spending what should have been his retirement 25,000 feet in the air.

articles.headline: Reince Priebus Is Ousted Amid Stormy Days for White House
articles.snippet: A six-month stint as President Trump’s top aide failed to impose order on an unruly and fractious White House.
articles.abstract: A six-month stint as President Trump’s top aide failed to impose order on an unruly and fractious White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Reince Priebus, the White House chief of staff who failed to impose order on a chaos-racked West Wing, was pushed out on Friday after a stormy six-month tenure, and President Trump replaced him with John F. Kelly, the secretary of homeland security and retired four-star Marine general.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Europe’s Luxury Retailers May Be Returning to Form
articles.snippet: As American rivals struggle to find growth, and after a torrid two years of trading, major European luxury brands are back on their feet.
articles.abstract: As American rivals struggle to find growth, and after a torrid two years of trading, major European luxury brands are back on their feet.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — On London’s Bond Street, home to some of the most expensive retail space in the world, only one store needs to instigate crowd control, the luxury brand of the moment: the Italian fashion and accessories powerhouse Gucci.

articles.headline: Behind Legislative Collapse: An Angry Vow Fizzles for Lack of a Viable Plan
articles.snippet: Voter anger turned Republicans against the Affordable Care Act, but amid the promises of repeal, the party never offered a viable alternative.
articles.abstract: Voter anger turned Republicans against the Affordable Care Act, but amid the promises of repeal, the party never offered a viable alternative.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The closing argument was a curious one: Vote yes, Republican leaders told the holdouts in their conference. We promise it will never become law.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer, Jonathan Martin and Jennifer Steinhauer

articles.headline: In Pivotal Moment, Tesla Unveils Its First Mass-Market Sedan
articles.snippet: Elon Musk, Tesla’s chief executive, delivered 30 cars to employees chosen to be the first owners. The electric-car maker faces a challenge in meeting the sizable demand.
articles.abstract: Elon Musk, Tesla’s chief executive, delivered 30 cars to employees chosen to be the first owners. The electric-car maker faces a challenge in meeting the sizable demand.
articles.lead_paragraph: FREMONT, Calif. — After a meteoric rise that made it, at least briefly, the most valuable car company in America, Tesla arrived at a moment of truth on Friday night as it delivered the first of its mass-market sedans to their new owners.

articles.headline: Utility Helps Wean Vermonters From the Electric Grid
articles.snippet: Green Mountain Power is trying to turn homes, neighborhoods and towns into virtual power plants, driven by economics as well as environmental goals.
articles.abstract: Green Mountain Power is trying to turn homes, neighborhoods and towns into virtual power plants, driven by economics as well as environmental goals.
articles.lead_paragraph: WALTHAM, Vt. — In a new low-income development that replaced a trailer park here, rooftop solar panels sparkle in the sun while backup batteries quietly hum away in utility closets.

articles.headline: Loss of Fertile Land Fuels ‘Looming Crisis’ Across Africa
articles.snippet: Climate change, soil degradation and rising wealth are shrinking the amount of usable land in Africa. But the number of people who need it is rising fast.
articles.abstract: Climate change, soil degradation and rising wealth are shrinking the amount of usable land in Africa. But the number of people who need it is rising fast.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAIKIPIA, Kenya — The two elders, wearing weather-beaten cowboy hats with the strings cinched under their chins, stood at the edge of an empty farm, covering their mouths in disbelief.

articles.headline: After North Korea Test, South Korea Pushes to Build Up Its Own Missiles
articles.snippet: North Korea’s launch of an intercontinental ballistic missile has spurred the South to seek arms talks with the United States.
articles.abstract: North Korea’s launch of an intercontinental ballistic missile has spurred the South to seek arms talks with the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — South Korea announced Saturday that it will soon start talks with the Trump administration about allowing Seoul to build more powerful ballistic missiles to counter the North, but current and former American officials said the move would have little effect on the most urgent problem facing Washington: North Korea’s apparent ability to strike California and beyond.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Trump Tries to Regroup as the West Wing Battles Itself
articles.snippet: President Trump faces hurdles after a staff shake-up and rising defiance by his own party.
articles.abstract: President Trump faces hurdles after a staff shake-up and rising defiance by his own party.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump enters a new phase of his presidency on Monday with a new chief of staff but an old set of challenges as he seeks to get back on course after enduring one of the worst weeks that any modern occupant of the Oval Office has experienced in his inaugural year in power.

articles.headline: Big Rigs, a Human Smuggling Mainstay, Often Become Rolling Traps
articles.snippet: The deaths of 10 migrants who had traveled in a tractor-trailer to San Antonio have cast a bright light on a practice known for its danger.
articles.abstract: The deaths of 10 migrants who had traveled in a tractor-trailer to San Antonio have cast a bright light on a practice known for its danger.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — In one truck, the migrants crouched in the dark in a three-foot crevice between the trailer’s ceiling and the top of medical-supply boxes. In another, smugglers crammed 73 men, women and children into a trailer filled with rotting watermelons, to try to disguise their scent for Border Patrol dogs.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez, Nicholas Kulish and Susan Anasagasti

articles.headline: A New Way for Therapists to Get Inside Heads: Virtual Reality
articles.snippet: Limbix, a start-up using Google headsets, helps psychologists expose patients to their anxieties in the safety of an office.
articles.abstract: Limbix, a start-up using Google headsets, helps psychologists expose patients to their anxieties in the safety of an office.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Dawn Jewell recently treated a patient haunted by a car crash. The patient had developed acute anxiety over the cross streets where the crash occurred, unable to drive a route that carried so many painful memories.

articles.headline: Putin, Responding to Sanctions, Orders U.S. to Cut Diplomatic Staff by 755
articles.snippet: The move was a major escalation in the Kremlin’s fight against a law passed in Congress last week expanding sanctions against Russia.
articles.abstract: The move was a major escalation in the Kremlin’s fight against a law passed in Congress last week expanding sanctions against Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin announced Sunday that the American diplomatic mission in Russia must reduce its staff by 755 employees, an aggressive response to new American sanctions that seemed ripped right from the Cold War playbook and sure to increase tensions between the two capitals.

articles.headline: MTV Mines the Past for Its Future: ‘Total Request Live’
articles.snippet: Remember the “TRL” studio and crowds in Times Square? Music? Carson Daly? MTV hopes you do, and will tune in again.
articles.abstract: Remember the “TRL” studio and crowds in Times Square? Music? Carson Daly? MTV hopes you do, and will tune in again.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a recent Wednesday afternoon, Chris McCarthy, the newish president of MTV, was standing at a corner of 44th Street and Broadway and gazing up at the second floor of Viacom’s Manhattan headquarters.

articles.headline: Republicans Worry That White House Disarray Is Undermining Trump
articles.snippet: A recent sequence of disappointments and blunders has rattled the president’s volatile governing coalition and threatens the G.O.P.’s policy agenda.
articles.abstract: A recent sequence of disappointments and blunders has rattled the president’s volatile governing coalition and threatens the G.O.P.’s policy agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump and Republicans in Washington have shaken the confidence of their supporters after a punishing and self-inflicted series of setbacks that have angered activists, left allies slack-jawed and reopened old fissures on the right.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Uber’s Search for New C.E.O. Hampered by Deep Split on Board
articles.snippet: The process for filling the ride-hailing company’s top job has been slowed by infighting and efforts by Travis Kalanick, who stepped down as chief executive last month, to stage a comeback.
articles.abstract: The process for filling the ride-hailing company’s top job has been slowed by infighting and efforts by Travis Kalanick, who stepped down as chief executive last month, to stage a comeback.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Some members of Uber’s eight-person board were excited about the idea of Meg Whitman becoming the ride-hailing company’s next chief executive.

articles.headline: Hacks and Leaks Pose New Challenges for Journalists. Next Up: Germany.
articles.snippet: News organizations in Germany are treating the American election as a case study in how not to empower forces bent on manipulating the electorate.
articles.abstract: News organizations in Germany are treating the American election as a case study in how not to empower forces bent on manipulating the electorate.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERLIN — To come here as an American on the eve of Germany’s next national political campaign is to go back in time to our own recent past, before the hacks and the (Wiki)leaks led to the paralyzing debate over whether Russia intervened in our presidential election.

articles.headline: Hot Spot for Tech Outsourcing: The United States
articles.snippet: As some American companies pull back from hiring programmers a world away, new tech jobs are cropping up across the country.
articles.abstract: As some American companies pull back from hiring programmers a world away, new tech jobs are cropping up across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, American companies have been saving money by “offshoring” jobs — hiring people in India and other distant cubicle farms.

articles.headline: London’s New Subway Symbolized the Future. Then Came Brexit.
articles.snippet: Crossrail is a megaproject meant to bind London together. But in the wake of Britain’s vote to leave the European Union, it may signal the end of an ambitious era.
articles.abstract: Crossrail is a megaproject meant to bind London together. But in the wake of Britain’s vote to leave the European Union, it may signal the end of an ambitious era.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Up an alley, beyond some hoarding, through what can feel like Harry Potter’s secret portal, the underworld of an unfinished Crossrail station sprawls beneath the traffic and commotion of Tottenham Court Road. Escalator banks descend through a sleek, silent black ticket hall where towering, empty, white-tiled passageways snake toward the new, vaulted train platform, curving like a half moon into the subterranean darkness.

articles.headline: New Dangers Stalk Syrian Children Still Haunted by Horrors Under ISIS
articles.snippet: Children born and raised under Islamic State rule have experienced and witnessed astonishing brutality, even by the cruel standards of the Syrian war.
articles.abstract: Children born and raised under Islamic State rule have experienced and witnessed astonishing brutality, even by the cruel standards of the Syrian war.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The boy did not want to see a beheading, so he held his mother’s hand tight and tried to close his eyes. But seeing it was mandatory when the Islamic State ruled his hometown in northern Syria: If you were out on the street, you had to watch.
articles.byline: By Somini Sengupta and Hwaida Saad

articles.headline: Discovery to Buy Scripps, Owner of Food Network, in $11.9 Billion Deal
articles.snippet: The agreement would add to consolidation in the telecommunications and media industries, as TV companies seek to better compete with cable and broadband providers.
articles.abstract: The agreement would add to consolidation in the telecommunications and media industries, as TV companies seek to better compete with cable and broadband providers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The cable TV business is a real fixer-upper.

articles.headline: John Kelly, Asserting Authority, Fires Anthony Scaramucci
articles.snippet: It remains to be seen if the new chief of staff will quell the chaos that has defined, distracted and often derailed President Trump’s White House.
articles.abstract: It remains to be seen if the new chief of staff will quell the chaos that has defined, distracted and often derailed President Trump’s White House.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — John F. Kelly, President Trump’s new chief of staff, firmly asserted his authority on his first day in the White House on Monday, telling aides he will impose military discipline on a free-for-all West Wing, and he underscored his intent by firing Anthony Scaramucci, the bombastic communications director, 10 days after he was hired.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear, Glenn Thrush and Maggie Haberman
